perturbation.original_text: The Producer shall have thirty (30) days from the payment date to dispute the amount of any revenue share payout or any such claim or dispute is hereby waived by the Producer.
perturbation.changed_text: The Producer shall have ten (10) days from the payment date to dispute the amount of any revenue share payout or any such claim or dispute is hereby waived by the Producer.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the dispute period to 10 days may be considered unreasonably short in Florida (governing law), potentially conflicting with principles of fairness and good faith, especially if the complexity of the revenue share calculation warrants a longer review period. This could be seen as an attempt to limit the Producer's ability to identify and challenge discrepancies.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Florida's implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.

perturbation.original_text: Notices shall be made by personal delivery, overnight courier, first class registered mail (postage prepaid and return receipt requested), facsimile or e-mail. A Notice shall be deemed served and received on the date executed on a receipt of acceptance or if by personal delivery, upon physical delivery of the same.
perturbation.changed_text: Notices shall be made exclusively by email. A Notice shall be deemed served and received upon sending the email.
perturbation.explanation: Restricting notices solely to email and deeming them served upon sending may conflict with Florida law regarding legal notices, especially concerning important contractual matters. Florida law often requires a method ensuring proof of receipt, particularly for actions with legal consequences. Email alone may not provide sufficient proof of delivery and receipt. Moreover, the legal system typically allows for multiple methods of service to make sure that a party can properly notify the other.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Florida Statutes regarding service of legal notices.

perturbation.original_text: The Parties expressly waive any claim to jurisdiction in any federal or other state forum or venue in any other county or place.
perturbation.changed_text: The Parties must resolve all disputes through binding arbitration and waive their right to pursue any form of litigation in any court, including waiving the right to a jury trial. The arbitrator's decision will be final and unappealable.
perturbation.explanation: While arbitration is generally enforceable, completely waiving the right to any form of judicial review, including appealing an arbitrator's decision, may be problematic under Florida law. Courts often retain limited jurisdiction to review arbitration awards for fraud, bias, or arbitrator misconduct. A complete waiver of appeal rights might be deemed unconscionable or against public policy if it effectively deprives a party of any meaningful recourse.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Florida Arbitration Code and Florida public policy regarding access to courts and due process.
